prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator set up: We wish to observe the 12CO 2-1, 13CO 2-1, C18O 2-1, and dust continuum simultaneously in band 6. The expected linewdiths of the sources are ~3.5 km/s, or 2.7MHz. Thus, we can acquire all observations together by using, in TDM mode, the correlator set up with with 117 MHz bandwidth, 60 kHz channel width for the line observations, and with 2GHz bandwidth, 31 MHz channel with for the dust continuum at 1mm. The 13CO and C18O observation will fit in the LSB, while the 12CO and dust continuum will fit in the USB.
Sensitivity: In the SMC, we expect the extended CO emission to have TMB(13CO 2-1) > 0.5 K. Typical linewidths are 3.5 km/s, and we will therefore bin the spectrum up to 1 km/s. To achieve S/N > 10 over 1 km/s, we request a sensitivity of 0.05 K (20 mJy) per beam per 1 km/s. Since the time to obtain a better sensitivity (14 mJY or 0.035 K) is similar, we request this better sensitivity.
The continuum observations will have a sensitivity of 0.5 mJy. Previous Herschel observations yield an expected continuum flux density of 5 mJy. The proposed sensitivity will give us at least S/N on the observations of the 1mm dust emission continuum.
Imaging: In the SMC, we expect the radius of of CO clouds to be typically 5-10 pc (20-30"). Thus we request a resolution of 3" to resolve the detailed structure of the CO emission. Our observations can therefore be performed in the most compact configuration of the 12 m array (best resolution of 1.62"). For this configuration, the maximum recoverable scale (MRS) is 11.4". Since the CO emission extends on scales larger than the MRS, the use of the ACA is required, to probe scales as large as 18". This is not sufficient to cover the extent of CO clouds in the SMC. Therefore, we request total power array observations as well. Simulations performed with Casapy 2.0 confirm that both the fine-scale structure and the extended emission are recovered with this set up. Lastly, we will obtain hexagonal 12 m array mosaics centered on our target coordinates to quadruple the coverage without incurring additional integration time or loss of sensitivity compared to a single pointing.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: LMC Band 6 12CO, 13CO, C18O 2-1, and 1 mm dust continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goals contain all the band 6 LMC observations: 12CO 2-1, 13CO2-1, C18O 12-1, and the dust continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator set up: We wish to observe the 12CO 2-1, 13CO 2-1, C18O 2-1, and dust continuum simultaneously in band 6. The expected linewdiths of the sources are ~3.5 km/s, or 2.7MHz. Thus, we can acquire all observations together by using, in TDM mode, the correlator set up with with 117 MHz bandwidth, 60 kHz channel width for the line observations, and with 2GHz bandwidth, 31 MHz channel with for the dust continuum at 1mm. The 13CO and C18O observation will fit in the LSB, while the 12CO and dust continuum will fit in the USB.
Sensitivity: In the LMC, we expect the extended CO emission to have TMB(13CO 2-1) > 1 K. Typical linewidths are 3.5 km/s, and we will therefore bin the spectrum up to 1 km/s. To achieve S/N > 10 over 1 km/s, we request a sensitivity of 0.1 K (40 mJy) per beam per 1 km/s. Since the time to obtain a better sensitivity (20 mJy or 0.05 K) is similar, we request this better sensitivity.
The continuum observations will have a sensitivity of 0.5 mJy. Previous Herschel observations yield an expected continuum flux density of 5 mJy. The proposed sensitivity will give us at least S/N on the observations of the 1mm dust emission continuum.
Imaging: In the LMC, we expect the radius of of CO clouds to be typically 15 pc (60"). Thus we request a resolution of 3" to resolve the detailed structure of the CO emission. Our observations can therefore be performed in the most compact configuration of the 12 m array (best resolution of 1.62"). For this configuration, the maximum recoverable scale (MRS) is 11.4". Since the CO emission extends on scales larger than the MRS, the use of the ACA is required, to probe scales as large as 18". This is not sufficient to cover the extent of CO clouds in the LMC. Therefore, we request total power array observations as well. Simulations performed with Casapy 2.0 confirm that both the fine-scale structure and the extended emission are recovered with this set up. Lastly, we will obtain hexagonal 12 m array mosaics centered on our target coordinates to quadruple the coverage without incurring additional integration time or loss of sensitivity compared to a single pointing.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: LMC Band 3 13CO and C18O 1-0
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goals contain all the band 6 LMC observations: 12CO 2-1, 13CO2-1, C18O 12-1, and the dust continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator set up: We wish to observe the 13CO 1-0 and C18O 1-0 simultaneously in band 3. The expected linewdiths of the sources are ~3.5 km/s, or 2.7MHz. Thus, we can acquire all observations together by using, in TDM mode, the correlator set up with with 58 MHz bandwidth, 30 kHz channel width for the line observations. The 13CO and C18O observation will both fit in the USB. We set the LSB window to observce the CS 2-1 line (since it comes for free).
Sensitivity: In the LMC, we expect the extended CO emission to have TMB(13CO 1-0) > 1 K. Typical linewidth are 3.5 km/s, and we will therefore bin the spectrum up to 1 km/s. To achieve S/N > 10 over 1 km/s, we request a sensitivity of 0.1 K (10 mJy) per beam per 1 km/s.
Imaging: In the LMC, we expect the radius of of CO clouds to be typically 15 pc (1'). Thus we request a resolution of 3" to resolve the detailed structure of the CO emission. Our observations can therefore be performed in the most compact configuration of the 12 m array (best resolution of 3"). For this configuration, the maximum recoverable scale (MRS) is 26". Since the CO emission extends on scales larger than the MRS, the use of the ACA is required, to probe scales as large as 42". This is not sufficient to cover the extent of CO clouds in the LMC. Therefore, we request total power array observations as well. Simulations performed with Casapy 2.0 confirm that both the fine-scale structure and the extended emission are recovered with this set up. Lastly, we will obtain hexagonal 12 m array mosaics centered on our target coordinates to quadruple the coverage without incurring additional integration time or loss of sensitivity compared to a single pointing.

Correlator set up: We wish to observe the 13CO 1-0 and C18O 1-0 simultaneously in band 3. The expected linewdiths of the sources are ~3.5 km/s, or 2.7MHz. Thus, we can acquire all observations together by using, in TDM mode, the correlator set up with with 58 MHz bandwidth, 30 kHz channel width for the line observations. The 13CO and C18O observation will both fit in the USB. We set the LSB window to observce the CS 2-1 line (since it comes for free).
Sensitivity: In the SMC, we expect the extended CO emission to have TMB(13CO 1-0) > 0.5 K. Typical linewidths are 3.5 km/s, and we will therefore bin the spectrum up to 1 km/s. To achieve S/N > 10 over 1 km/s, we request a sensitivity of 0.05 K (5 mJy) per beam per 1 km/s.
Imaging: In the SMC, we expect the radius of of CO clouds to be typically 5-10 pc (20-30"). Thus we request a resolution of 3" to resolve the detailed structure of the CO emission. Our observations can therefore be performed in the most compact configuration of the 12 m array (best resolution of 3"). For this configuration, the maximum recoverable scale (MRS) is 26". Since the CO emission extends on scales larger than the MRS, the use of the ACA and TP arrays is required, to probe scales as large as 42". Simulations performed with Casapy 2.0 confirm that both the fine-scale structure and the extended emission are recovered with this set up. Lastly, we will obtain hexagonal 12 m array mosaics centered on our target coordinates to quadruple the coverage without incurring additional integration time or loss of sensitivity compared to a single pointing.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: LMC band 3 12CO 1-0
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goals contain all the band 6 LMC observations: 12CO 2-1, 13CO2-1, C18O 12-1, and the dust continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Correlator set up: We wish to observe the 12CO 1-0 in band 3. The expected linewdiths of the sources are ~3.5 km/s, or 2.7MHz. Thus, we can acquire all observations together by using, in TDM mode, the correlator set up with with 58 MHz bandwidth, 30 kHz channel width for the line observations.
Sensitivity: In the LMC, we expect the extended CO emission to have TMB(12CO 1-0) > 2-5 K. Typical linewidths are 3.5 km/s, and we will therefore bin the spectrum up to 1 km/s. To achieve S/N > 10 over 1 km/s, we request a sensitivity of 0.25 K (25 mJy) per beam per 1 km/s.
Imaging: In the LMC, we expect the radius of of CO clouds to be typically 15 pc (1'). Thus we request a resolution of 3" to resolve the detailed structure of the CO emission. Our observations can therefore be performed in the most compact configuration of the 12 m array (best resolution of 3"). For this configuration, the maximum recoverable scale (MRS) is 26". Since the CO emission extends on scales larger than the MRS, the use of the ACA is required, to probe scales as large as 42". This is not sufficient to cover the extent of CO clouds in the LMC. Therefore, we request total power array observations as well. Simulations performed with Casapy 2.0 confirm that both the fine-scale structure and the extended emission are recovered with this set up. Lastly, we will obtain hexagonal 12 m array mosaics centered on our target coordinates to quadruple the coverage without incurring additional integration time or loss of sensitivity compared to a single pointing.

Correlator set up: We wish to observe the 12CO 1-0 in band 3. The expected linewdiths of the sources are ~3.5 km/s, or 2.7MHz. Thus, we can acquire all observations together by using, in TDM mode, the correlator set up with with 58 MHz bandwidth, 30 kHz channel width for the line observations.
Sensitivity: In the SMC, we expect the extended CO emission to have TMB(12CO 1-0) > 2-5 K. Typical linewidths are 3.5 km/s, and we will therefore bin the spectrum up to 1 km/s. To achieve S/N > 10 over 1 km/s, we request a sensitivity of 0.25 K (25 mJy) per beam per 1 km/s.
Imaging: In the SMC, we expect the radius of of CO clouds to be typically 5-10 pc (up tp 30"). Thus we request a resolution of 3" to resolve the detailed structure of the CO emission. Our observations can therefore be performed in the most compact configuration of the 12 m array (best resolution of 3"). For this configuration, the maximum recoverable scale (MRS) is 26". Since the CO emission extends on scales larger than the MRS, the use of the ACA is required, to probe scales as large as 42". This is not sufficient to cover the extent of CO clouds in the LMC. Therefore, we request total power array observations as well. Simulations performed with Casapy 2.0 confirm that both the fine-scale structure and the extended emission are recovered with this set up. Lastly, we will obtain hexagonal 12 m array mosaics centered on our target coordinates to quadruple the coverage without incurring additional integration time or loss of sensitivity compared to a single pointing.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The structure of CO emission is expected to change with metallicity and radiation field. In particular, the level of extended emission, and the size of CO "clumps", are expected to decrease as metallicity decreases or radiation field strength increases. This effect has never been directly observed before, and models of CO formation have not been put to a test. We propose to obtain maps of two transitions (1-0 and 2-1) of three CO isotopes (12CO, 13CO, and C18O) in two low-metallicity galaxies, the LMC and the SMC. Our 6 targets (3 in the LMC, 3 in the SMC) cover a range of radiation field intensities and star formation rates. These observations will yield deep maps of the CO column density and of the thermal and chemical state of the gas. We will not only observe for the first time the pc scale structure of CO emitting gas at low metallicity, but we will also calibrate the X factor as a function of spatial scale, radiation field and metallicity. These observations will therefore have a large impact on studies of H2 gas in more distant low-metallicity galaxies, by improving our ability to accurately determine H2 gas masses from the optically thick 12CO transition only.
